title: 105_hr1227
content: The Act may be cited as the "Internal Revenue Service Accountability Act" and includes a criminal penalty for certain unauthorized actions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new paragraph (10) that penalizes officers or employees who willfully disregard tax laws or regulations in proceedings against taxpayers. The penalty is a fine of $10,000 ($1,000 for offenses under paragraph 10), imprisonment up to 5 years (1 year for offenses under paragraph 10), or both. The amendments made by this section apply to actions by officers or employees after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. IRS employees personally liable for damages and litigation costs in certain cases. IRS employees may be personally liable for litigation costs if the court finds their actions to be arbitrary, capricious, or malicious. Upon request, IRS officers or employees may be represented by the United States in proceedings regarding assessments against them. If found liable, they must repay the costs of representation. Additionally, Section 7432 of the Internal Revenue Code addresses civil damages and court costs for failure to release a lien. Section 7432 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for personal liability of IRS officers and employees in cases where damages are awarded for arbitrary, capricious, or malicious acts. Officers or employees found liable will not be reimbursed by the United States for assessed damages. Section 7433 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for civil damages and court costs for certain unauthorized collection actions. An employee, including a former officer or employee, may be represented by the United States in proceedings regarding assessments. If the officer or employee is found liable, they must repay the United States for the representation costs. The Internal Revenue Code allows for civil damages for unauthorized collection actions. A new subsection allows courts to assess damages against IRS officers or employees if their actions are deemed arbitrary, capricious, or malicious. Officers or employees, including former ones, may be held personally liable for damages awarded to plaintiffs. The Internal Revenue Code allows for civil damages for unauthorized collection actions, with a new subsection allowing courts to assess damages against IRS officers or employees for arbitrary, capricious, or malicious actions. Officers or employees, including former ones, may be personally liable for damages awarded to plaintiffs. The amendments made by this section apply to proceedings commenced after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. PROTECTING THE PRIVACY OF TAXPAYERS. Amendment to Section 7431 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes penalties for unauthorized access of returns and return information. This amendment covers disclosure, access, and notification related to unauthorized access of taxpayer information. Amendment to Section 7213(a)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds criminal penalties for unauthorized access of returns and return information. It prohibits willful access without authorization to any return or return information. The amendment to Section 7213(a)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces criminal penalties for unauthorized access to returns and return information, including dismissal from office or employment, a misdemeanor charge with a fine up to $1,000, imprisonment up to 1 year, or both. Unauthorized access is prohibited except as authorized by law. The amendment prohibits unauthorized access to tax returns and information by US officers or employees, with immediate notification required if a violation occurs. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code, and the effective date applies to actions post-enactment. SEC. 5. LIMITATIONS ON EXAMINATIONS. Section 7602 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to limit the Secretary's authority to examine tax returns. The Secretary must provide reasonable justification for initiating an examination and cannot reexamine a return that has already been examined or extend an examination beyond a 3-taxable-year period. The amendment to Section 7602 of the Internal Revenue Code limits the Secretary's authority to examine tax returns, requiring justification for initiation and prohibiting reexamination of previously examined returns. The effective date for this amendment applies to examinations initiated after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6 amends the time to pay tax after notice and demand from 21 to 90 calendar days. SEC. 7 introduces a new section for declaratory judgments relating to secretarial nonacquiescence in judicial proceedings. SEC. 7436 allows for declaratory judgments in cases where the Secretary does not acquiesce with legal conclusions in similar cases. The district court can issue a declaration with the same effect as a final judgment. SEC. 7436 allows for declaratory judgments relating to secretarial nonacquiescence. SEC. 7437 provides cross references. The amendments made by this section apply to court proceedings initiated after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 8 limits asset seizures and levies by requiring consent of an appropriate court. The effective date for this amendment is after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 9 states that there will be no interest on penalties, additional amounts, and additions to tax. SEC. 9 amends the Internal Revenue Code to state that no interest will be imposed on penalties, additional amounts, or additions to tax. The effective date for this amendment is after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 10 amends the Internal Revenue Code to equalize the interest rate for overpayments and underpayments. The Federal short-term rate will be used for both rates. The amendment is effective for interest calculations after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 11 amends Section 6404(d) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow for the abatement of interest, penalty, additional amount, and addition to tax in cases of mathematical or clerical errors. The amendment applies to notices filed after the enactment of the Act.
